subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Why does 1 digital recorder capture EVP over another
author: Zack Widup
full_text:
Interesting topic!

BTW that investigation was at the former Manteno State Mental Hospital. It
included the amazing "It's Harold Wing" EVP I got. None of the people doing
the investigation there had ever heard of Harold Wing. Upon later
examination of old records, it was found that Harold Wing was actually a
patient who died there of typhoid fever in 1938. But we didn't find that out
until weeks later.
How do you explain that conventionally?
:-)

Zack


On Wed, Jun 24, 2009 at 8:36 AM, April Abercrombie <
april@abercrombieghostresearch.com> wrote:

>
>
>  A similar thing happened to me on our last investigation too.
>
>
>  ----- Original Message -----
> *From:* Zack Widup <w9sz.zack@...>
> *To:* EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
>   *Sent:* Wednesday, June 24, 2009 7:19 AM
> *Subject:* Re: [EVP-ITC] Why does 1 digital recorder capture EVP over
> another
>
>  There's another possibility: possibly the spirits involved only wish to
> impart sounds to a particular unit or units.
>
> I was surprised on one investigation I was on to get mostly all the same
> EVP on my DVR, which was hanging from my belt, and my camcorder, which was
> in front of my face. Other people on the investigation didn't get them at
> all. Go figure!
> :-)
>
> Zack
>
> On Tue, Jun 23, 2009 at 3:26 PM, Rj <rasterer@...> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>>   There could be several reasons, and it's only conjecture without
>> comparing the two specific units in questions.  But some ideas:
>>
>> 1) The battery level on one is different than the other, and causing one
>> to function less optimally and introduce noise or artifacts into the stream.
>> 2) They were not actually 'sitting' side by side, but being swung around.
>> 3) They are pointed at different areas
>> 4) One may be older than the other or have been dropped a few times.
>> 5) One may have been recently exposed to extreme humidity or temperatures,
>> while the other remained in a comfortable environment, before doing this
>> recording
>> 6) One may be sitting in a position more subject by airflow or vibrations
>> 7) They may use different memory cards. that have different error or
>> accuracy profiles
>> 8) The final sound files may have been processed differently in various
>> software programs
>> 9) People in the room may be nearer and moving closer to one than the
>> other
>> 10) They may simply be two different models with different recording
>> sensitives and limitations
>>
>>
>>
>> --- On *Tue, 6/23/09, lechevar2000 <lechevar@...>* wrote:
>>
>>
>> From: lechevar2000 <lechevar@verizon.net>
>> Subject: [EVP-ITC] Why does 1 digital recorder capture EVP over another
>> To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
>> Date: Tuesday, June 23, 2009, 5:57 AM
>>
>>  Hi,
>> I believe I saw an explaination on this list about why if you have 2
>> recorders sitting side by side, why may one capture an EVP on one and not
>> the other? Someone was explaining about an energy field like a bubble.
>> I'm trying to explain this theory to a friend. Can someone help me?
>> Thanks Laura
>>
>>
>>
>   
>

Zack
